queue_manager module¶

This module contains following classes: QueueManager, QueueClient, QueueServer.

You can run this module directly to start the server. The server bind to address and port, which are specified in settings.

$ python queue_manager.py
class QueueManager[source]¶

Bases: object

This class holds and manage all queues.

Note

Do not use this class directly. Instead use QueueClient to connect to the QueueServer and get an instance of this class.

next_host()[source]¶

Getting next hostname of the appropriate queue.

Return str:hostname e.g. “google.com”
empty_queue()[source]¶
Empty entire queue.

Note

use this function with care. it will empty the whole host_queue. even if the host_queue has not finished yet.

put_user_list(user_list)[source]¶
Parameters:user_list (list) –
Returns:
put_new_list(new_list)[source]¶

Empty and refill the queue.

Parameters:new_list (list) – nested list with hostname and source e.g. [ [“google.com”, [“alexa-top-1m”, ] ], ]
next_result()[source]¶

Getting next result from result_queue.

Return tuple:({sslyze result}, [source,])
put_result(result)[source]¶

Putting result to result_queue.

Parameters:result –
Returns:
class QueueClient(address=('localhost', 50001), authkey='abc')[source]¶

Bases: multiprocessing.managers.BaseManager

This class is used to connect to QueueServer.

If you instantiate this class it will auto connect to the server. So you can get an instance by name of each registered object.

Example: 
from queue_manager import QueueClient

c = QueueClient()

# registered name is "queue_manager" , so you can call it to get
# the instance of QueueManager class.
queue_manager = c.queue_manger()

# do something with queue_manager ...
